page.title: 08THE MORRITT ARMS
page.content: The coaching days of the 18th century saw the opening up of the road from Scotch Corner to Penrith as a main route in the link between Glasgow and London. Greta Bridge was one of the recognised stopping places with three coaching inns in the village. Railways took much traffic from the roads so the Morritt Arms is the only one left. In 1920 it was much modernised to take advantage of the fact that cars were bringing traffic back to the roads. By 1960 traffic was so heavy it posed its own threat to trade. But now the village is by-passed. Now the Morritt Arms is a quiet hotel of character, close to a busy main road, but with good access and parking. It welcomes the locals, the passing traveller and increasingly functions such as weddings and party bookings or commercial gatherings.
